texts.shortText: Unusually short, stout-bodied amphipod with wide, hairy legs that curve around to form a cavity beneath the body. Antennae short and eyes small in females, but antenna 2 much longer and eyes much larger in males. The 5th pair of legs particularly broad and last segment bearing about 7 sharp spines along anterior margin. Abdominal appendages strong and used to propel a stream of water beneath body and thus drive the animal forwards though the sediment.

Global: Europe, Mediterranean and South Africa.

Local/Regional: Namibia to about Algoa Bay.

Burrows through sand on beaches and sheltered lagoons much like a mole. The short, wide body and wide legs enclose a tunnel-like ventral space beneath the body and beating of the strong abdominal appendages within this chamber creates a strong water current which drives the animal forward within the sand.
Assumed to scavenger on food particles attached to sand grains that are pumped thought the ventral body cavity by beating of the abdominal appendages.

As with all amphipods, the eggs are retained within a marsupial chamber between the walking legs of the female, where they develop into fully-formed juveniles prior to release. Reproduction has not been studied in South African populations, but in European species the number of eggs is low at about 15 per brood, maturity is reached in about five months and longevity seldom exceeds one year.

The group is fairly easily identified by the unusually short, squat body and wide legs highly adapted for the burrowing lifestyle. In South Africa this genus is represented by at least 8 similar species that differ mainly in the width and shape of the segments on the 5th (and sometimes 6th and 7th) walking legs. This species is unusual in having a row of about 7 anterior spines along the last segment of leg 5. For a full key to species see Griffiths reference below.

Branch G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town (p. 96).

Griffiths, CL (1976). Guide to the benthic marine amphipods of Southern Africa. Trustees of the South African Museum (p. 46).
